definition_brief: Long bone of the upper arm extending from shoulder to elbow, articulating with scapula proximally and radius/ulna distally
description_full: The humerus is the longest and largest bone of the upper limb. It articulates proximally with the glenoid cavity of the scapula at the glenohumeral joint and distally with the radius and ulna at the elbow joint. The bone consists of a proximal end, shaft, and distal end with numerous important anatomical landmarks.
clinical_significance: **Fractures** are common, particularly of the surgical neck in elderly patients and midshaft in younger individuals. **Radial nerve injury** may occur with midshaft fractures. **Supracondylar fractures** in children can compromise brachial artery flow. The humerus is a common site for **metastatic lesions** and **pathological fractures**.
blood_supply: Profunda brachii artery (shaft), anterior and posterior humeral circumflex arteries (proximal end), radial and ulnar collateral arteries (distal end)

definition_brief: Smooth, rounded articular surface forming approximately one-third of a sphere, articulating with the glenoid cavity
description_full: The head of the humerus is a large, smooth, rounded eminence that forms the proximal articular surface of the humerus. It is directed medially, upward, and backward, forming about one-third of a sphere. The articular surface is covered with hyaline cartilage and is separated from the greater and lesser tubercles by the anatomical neck.
clinical_significance: The humeral head is frequently affected in **shoulder dislocations** (typically anterior). **Avascular necrosis** can occur following fractures or steroid use. **Hill-Sachs lesion** (impaction fracture) occurs with anterior shoulder dislocation. **Osteoarthritis** commonly affects this joint surface in elderly patients.
blood_supply: Anterior and posterior humeral circumflex arteries, arcuate artery

definition_brief: Large, lateral prominence on proximal humerus providing attachment for rotator cuff muscles
description_full: The greater tubercle is a large, prominent projection situated lateral to the head and lesser tubercle. It presents three impressions or facets: the superior facet for supraspinatus, the middle facet for infraspinatus, and the inferior facet for teres minor. It forms the lateral boundary of the intertubercular groove.
clinical_significance: **Rotator cuff tears** commonly involve the tendons inserting here. **Greater tuberosity fractures** often accompany anterior shoulder dislocations. **Impingement syndrome** involves compression of rotator cuff tendons between the acromion and greater tubercle. Chronic impingement can lead to **bony spurring**.
insertion: Supraspinatus (superior facet), infraspinatus (middle facet), teres minor (inferior facet)
blood_supply: Anterior and posterior humeral circumflex arteries

definition_brief: Smaller, anterior prominence on proximal humerus serving as attachment for subscapularis muscle
description_full: The lesser tubercle is a smaller prominence located anterior to the greater tubercle and lateral to the head of the humerus. It projects anteriorly and provides attachment for the subscapularis tendon. It forms the medial boundary of the intertubercular (bicipital) groove.
clinical_significance: **Subscapularis tears** affect this insertion site. **Lesser tuberosity fractures** are less common than greater tuberosity fractures but may occur with posterior shoulder dislocations. The lesser tubercle is an important landmark in **shoulder arthroscopy** and **surgical approaches** to the glenohumeral joint.
blood_supply: Anterior humeral circumflex artery

definition_brief: Vertical groove between greater and lesser tubercles containing the tendon of the long head of biceps brachii
description_full: The intertubercular groove (bicipital groove) is a deep furrow running vertically down the anterior surface of the proximal humerus between the greater and lesser tubercles. It contains the tendon of the long head of biceps brachii enclosed in a synovial sheath. The floor and walls provide attachment for pectoralis major, latissimus dorsi, and teres major.
clinical_significance: **Bicipital tendinitis** causes pain in this groove. **Subluxation or dislocation** of the biceps tendon from the groove causes anterior shoulder pain and a palpable snap. **Fractures** involving the groove can disrupt the biceps tendon pathway. The groove is an important landmark during **shoulder surgery**.
insertion: Pectoralis major (lateral lip), latissimus dorsi (floor), teres major (medial lip)
blood_supply: Anterior humeral circumflex artery

definition_brief: V-shaped roughened area on lateral mid-shaft of humerus serving as insertion for deltoid muscle
description_full: The deltoid tuberosity is a rough, V-shaped elevation on the lateral surface of the humeral shaft, approximately at its midpoint. It provides the insertion for the deltoid muscle and marks an important anatomical landmark dividing the proximal and distal portions of the shaft.
clinical_significance: The **axillary nerve and posterior humeral circumflex artery** pass posterior to the surgical neck near this landmark. **Midshaft fractures** at or near the deltoid tuberosity may result in **radial nerve injury**. The tuberosity is an important reference point during **open reduction and internal fixation** of humeral fractures.
blood_supply: Profunda brachii artery (deep brachial artery)

definition_brief: Prominent medial bony projection at distal humerus providing origin for forearm flexor muscles
description_full: The medial epicondyle is a large, prominent projection on the medial aspect of the distal humerus. It provides origin for the common flexor tendon (flexor-pronator group) and the ulnar collateral ligament. Posterior to the epicondyle is a groove for the ulnar nerve.
clinical_significance: **Medial epicondylitis** (golfer's elbow) affects the common flexor origin. **Ulnar nerve** compression or injury commonly occurs in the groove posterior to the epicondyle, causing **cubital tunnel syndrome**. **Pediatric fractures** may involve the medial epicondyle apophysis. The epicondyle is easily palpable and serves as a key **anatomical landmark**.
origin: Pronator teres, flexor carpi radialis, palmaris longus, flexor carpi ulnaris, flexor digitorum superficialis (common flexor origin)
blood_supply: Superior and inferior ulnar collateral arteries

definition_brief: Lateral bony prominence at distal humerus providing origin for forearm extensor muscles
description_full: The lateral epicondyle is a small, tuberculated eminence on the lateral aspect of the distal humerus. It provides origin for the common extensor tendon (extensor-supinator group) and the radial collateral ligament. It is less prominent than the medial epicondyle.
clinical_significance: **Lateral epicondylitis** (tennis elbow) is a common overuse injury affecting the common extensor origin, particularly extensor carpi radialis brevis. **Fractures** are less common than medial epicondyle fractures but can disrupt elbow mechanics. The lateral epicondyle serves as an important **palpable landmark** during elbow examination.
origin: Extensor carpi radialis brevis, extensor digitorum, extensor digiti minimi, extensor carpi ulnaris (common extensor origin), supinator
blood_supply: Radial collateral artery, radial recurrent artery

definition_brief: Rounded articular eminence on lateral distal humerus articulating with the head of the radius
description_full: The capitulum (capitellum) is a smooth, rounded articular surface on the lateral part of the distal humerus. It articulates with the concave superior surface of the radial head, allowing for flexion-extension and pronation-supination movements at the elbow joint. The capitulum is hemispherical and projects anteriorly.
clinical_significance: **Panner's disease** (osteochondrosis) and **osteochondritis dissecans** can affect the capitulum in children and adolescents. **Capitellar fractures** may occur with falls on outstretched hand. **Avascular necrosis** can occur post-trauma. The capitulum is visualized on **lateral elbow radiographs** and important in assessing elbow alignment.
blood_supply: Radial collateral artery, radial recurrent artery

definition_brief: Pulley-shaped articular surface on medial distal humerus articulating with the trochlear notch of ulna
description_full: The trochlea is a pulley-shaped articular surface on the medial portion of the distal humerus. It articulates with the trochlear notch of the ulna, forming a hinge joint that permits flexion and extension. The medial lip of the trochlea projects distally more than the lateral lip, contributing to the carrying angle of the elbow.
clinical_significance: **Fractures** of the trochlea can result in elbow instability and malunion leading to **cubitus valgus** or **cubitus varus** deformity. The trochlea's asymmetry creates the normal **carrying angle** (5-15 degrees). **Elbow dislocation** typically involves separation at the trochlea-ulnar articulation. Assessment of trochlear anatomy is critical in **pediatric elbow trauma**.
blood_supply: Superior and inferior ulnar collateral arteries, anterior and posterior ulnar recurrent arteries

definition_brief: Deep depression on posterior distal humerus receiving the olecranon process during elbow extension
description_full: The olecranon fossa is a deep, triangular depression on the posterior surface of the distal humerus, superior to the trochlea. It receives the olecranon process of the ulna when the forearm is extended, allowing complete extension at the elbow joint. It is often separated from the coronoid fossa anteriorly by only a thin plate of bone.
clinical_significance: **Supracondylar fractures** may communicate between olecranon and coronoid fossae if the intervening bone is thin. **Elbow effusion** distends the olecranon fossa, producing a positive **posterior fat pad sign** on lateral radiographs. **Loose bodies** or osteophytes in this fossa can limit extension. The fossa may be deepened surgically to increase extension range.
blood_supply: Profunda brachii artery, superior and inferior ulnar collateral arteries

definition_brief: Large, flat, triangular bone on posterior thoracic wall providing attachment for shoulder and back muscles
description_full: The scapula is a large, flat, triangular bone situated on the posterolateral aspect of the thorax, overlying ribs 2-7. It consists of a body with costal and dorsal surfaces, three borders (superior, medial, lateral), three angles (superior, inferior, lateral), and important processes (spine, acromion, coracoid). It forms part of the shoulder girdle and provides extensive muscle attachments.
clinical_significance: **Scapular fractures** typically result from high-energy trauma and may indicate severe chest injuries. **Winging of scapula** occurs with long thoracic nerve palsy (serratus anterior paralysis). **Scapular dyskinesis** contributes to shoulder impingement. **Frozen shoulder** affects scapulothoracic rhythm. The scapula serves as a key landmark for **posterior thoracic procedures**.
origin: Deltoid (spine), supraspinatus (supraspinous fossa), infraspinatus (infraspinous fossa), subscapularis (subscapular fossa), triceps brachii long head (infraglenoid tubercle), biceps brachii long head (supraglenoid tubercle), coracobrachialis (coracoid process)
insertion: Serratus anterior (medial border), rhomboids (medial border), levator scapulae (superior angle), trapezius (spine and acromion), pectoralis minor (coracoid process)
blood_supply: Suprascapular artery, dorsal scapular artery, subscapular artery, circumflex scapular artery

definition_brief: Prominent triangular ridge traversing the dorsal surface of scapula, dividing it into supraspinous and infraspinous fossae
description_full: The spine of the scapula is a strong, triangular plate of bone that projects posteriorly from the dorsal surface of the scapula. It begins medially at the vertebral border as a smooth triangular area and gradually increases in height laterally, terminating in the acromion process. The spine divides the posterior scapula into supraspinous and infraspinous fossae.
clinical_significance: The spine is a key **palpable landmark** for shoulder examination and **regional anesthesia** (suprascapular nerve blocks). **Scapular spine fractures** are rare but may occur with direct trauma. The spine serves as an important **reference point** during shoulder arthroscopy and **posterior surgical approaches**. It is a common site for **muscle strain** attachment injuries.
blood_supply: Suprascapular artery, dorsal scapular artery

definition_brief: Lateral extension of scapular spine forming the highest point of shoulder and articulating with clavicle
description_full: The acromion is a large, flat process that projects anterolaterally from the lateral end of the scapular spine. It overhangs the glenoid cavity and articulates with the lateral end of the clavicle at the acromioclavicular joint. The acromion has superior and inferior surfaces and provides attachment for deltoid and trapezius muscles.
clinical_significance: **Acromial morphology** (type I-III classification) influences **rotator cuff impingement** risk. **Acromioclavicular joint separation** is common in contact sports. **Os acromiale** (unfused acromial ossification center) may be mistaken for fracture. **Subacromial bursitis** occurs beneath the acromion. The acromion is a key landmark for **shoulder injection** and **surgical approaches**.
blood_supply: Thoracoacromial artery, suprascapular artery

definition_brief: Hook-like projection extending anterolaterally from superior scapula, providing attachment for muscles and ligaments
description_full: The coracoid process is a thick, curved projection that extends anterolaterally from the superior border of the scapula, lateral to the suprascapular notch. It resembles a bent finger and provides attachment for pectoralis minor, coracobrachialis, biceps brachii short head, and the coracoclavicular and coracoacromial ligaments. It lies deep to the anterior deltoid.
clinical_significance: **Coracoid fractures** may occur with shoulder trauma or anterior shoulder dislocation. **Coracoid impingement** can cause anterior shoulder pain. The coracoid serves as a landmark for **infraclavicular brachial plexus blocks**. **Pectoralis minor syndrome** involves neurovascular compression at the coracoid. The process is a key reference in **shoulder arthroscopy**.
blood_supply: Thoracoacromial artery, suprascapular artery

definition_brief: Shallow, pyriform articular cavity on lateral angle of scapula articulating with humeral head
description_full: The glenoid cavity is a shallow, pyriform (pear-shaped) articular surface located on the lateral angle of the scapula. It is directed anterolaterally and slightly superiorly. The cavity is deepened by the fibrocartilaginous glenoid labrum and articulates with the much larger head of the humerus, forming the glenohumeral joint. The cavity is approximately one-third the size of the humeral head.
clinical_significance: The shallow glenoid provides **minimal bony stability**, making anterior shoulder **dislocations** common. **Bankart lesions** (labral tears with bony avulsion) occur with recurrent dislocation. **Glenoid fractures** result from high-energy trauma. **Osteoarthritis** commonly affects the glenoid surface. **Reverse shoulder arthroplasty** reconstructs the glenoid in rotator cuff arthropathy.
origin: Biceps brachii long head (supraglenoid tubercle), triceps brachii long head (infraglenoid tubercle)
blood_supply: Suprascapular artery, circumflex scapular artery

definition_brief: S-shaped long bone connecting sternum to scapula, forming the anterior portion of shoulder girdle
description_full: The clavicle is a subcutaneous, S-shaped long bone that extends horizontally across the root of the neck from the sternum to the acromion of the scapula. It is convex anteriorly in its medial two-thirds and concave anteriorly in its lateral third. The bone serves as a strut supporting the upper limb and transmitting forces from the limb to the axial skeleton.
clinical_significance: **Clavicular fractures** are among the most common fractures, typically occurring at the junction of middle and lateral thirds. **Birth trauma** can cause clavicle fracture. The bone overlies the **subclavian vessels and brachial plexus**, risking neurovascular injury with fracture or surgery. **Sternoclavicular dislocation** is rare but can be life-threatening posteriorly. The clavicle is the **first bone to ossify** and **last to fuse**.
origin: Deltoid (anterior border lateral third), trapezius (posterior border lateral third), sternocleidomastoid (superior surface medial third), pectoralis major (anterior surface medial half)
blood_supply: Suprascapular artery, thoracoacromial artery, internal thoracic artery

definition_brief: Lateral bone of forearm, shorter than ulna, articulating with capitulum proximally and carpal bones distally
description_full: The radius is the lateral bone of the forearm, positioned on the thumb side. It is shorter than the ulna and characterized by a small proximal end and an expanded distal end. The radius articulates with the capitulum of the humerus proximally, the ulna medially, and the scaphoid and lunate distally. It rotates around the ulna during pronation and supination.
clinical_significance: **Distal radius fractures** (Colles', Smith's) are extremely common, especially in elderly patients with osteoporosis. **Radial head fractures** occur with falls on outstretched hand. **Galeazzi fracture** involves radial shaft with distal radioulnar joint disruption. The **radial styloid** is a common site for **de Quervain's tenosynovitis**. **Growth plate injuries** are common in children.
origin: Flexor digitorum superficialis (anterior oblique line), flexor pollicis longus (anterior surface), pronator teres (lateral surface mid-shaft)
insertion: Supinator (proximal third), biceps brachii (radial tuberosity), pronator quadratus (distal quarter anterior surface), brachioradialis (styloid process)
blood_supply: Radial artery, anterior and posterior interosseous arteries

definition_brief: Disc-shaped proximal end of radius articulating with capitulum and radial notch of ulna
description_full: The head of the radius is a disc-shaped structure forming the proximal end of the bone. Its superior surface is concave and articulates with the capitulum of the humerus. The circumference of the head is smooth and articulates with the radial notch of the ulna and is encircled by the annular ligament. The head allows for both flexion-extension and pronation-supination.
clinical_significance: **Radial head fractures** are common elbow injuries, classified by Mason classification. **Radial head subluxation** (nursemaid's elbow) is common in young children. **Excision** of the radial head may be performed for comminuted fractures. **Prosthetic replacement** may be necessary for complex fractures. The radial head contributes to **longitudinal stability** of the forearm.
blood_supply: Radial recurrent artery

definition_brief: Oval prominence on medial aspect of proximal radius serving as insertion for biceps brachii tendon
description_full: The radial tuberosity is an oval prominence on the medial aspect of the radius, just distal to the neck. It provides insertion for the biceps brachii tendon. The tuberosity has a rough posterior part and a smooth anterior part, which is separated from the biceps tendon by the bicipitoradial bursa.
clinical_significance: **Bicipitoradial bursitis** can cause antecubital pain aggravated by pronation-supination. **Biceps tendon rupture** may avulse the tuberosity. The tuberosity's position changes during **pronation-supination**, affecting mechanical advantage of biceps. **Heterotopic ossification** can occur post-trauma. The tuberosity is an important landmark during **radial head excision**.
blood_supply: Radial recurrent artery, radial artery

definition_brief: Conical projection extending distally from lateral aspect of distal radius
description_full: The radial styloid process is a large, conical projection that extends distally from the lateral aspect of the distal radius. It provides attachment for the brachioradialis muscle and the radial collateral ligament of the wrist. The styloid process extends approximately 1 cm more distally than the ulnar styloid, contributing to ulnar deviation of the hand at the wrist.
clinical_significance: The styloid is a key landmark for assessing **radial length** on radiographs. **Fractures** of the styloid can occur in isolation or with distal radius fractures. **de Quervain's tenosynovitis** affects tendons passing over the styloid. The **anatomic snuffbox** is bounded posteriorly by the styloid. **Intersection syndrome** occurs proximal to the styloid.
blood_supply: Radial artery

definition_brief: Medial bone of forearm, longer than radius, with large proximal end and small distal head
description_full: The ulna is the medial and longer of the two forearm bones, positioned on the little finger side. It is characterized by a large proximal end with the olecranon and coronoid processes, and a small, rounded distal head. The ulna articulates with the trochlea of the humerus proximally and with the radius via the ulnar notch throughout its length. Unlike the radius, the ulna does not articulate directly with the carpal bones.
clinical_significance: **Monteggia fracture** involves proximal ulnar shaft fracture with radial head dislocation. **Nightstick fracture** is an isolated ulnar shaft fracture from direct blow. **Ulnar impaction syndrome** causes ulnar-sided wrist pain. **Coronoid fractures** affect elbow stability. The **subcutaneous border** makes the ulna vulnerable to direct trauma and easily palpable for examination.
origin: Flexor carpi ulnaris (medial epicondyle and olecranon), flexor digitorum profundus (anterior and medial surfaces), extensor carpi ulnaris (posterior border), flexor digitorum superficialis (coronoid process), pronator teres (coronoid process), brachialis (coronoid process and tuberosity)
blood_supply: Ulnar artery, anterior and posterior interosseous arteries, radial artery

definition_brief: Large, curved proximal projection of ulna forming point of elbow and providing insertion for triceps brachii
description_full: The olecranon is a large, thick, curved eminence at the proximal end of the ulna. It projects proximally and slightly posteriorly, forming the bony prominence of the elbow. Its posterior surface is subcutaneous and easily palpable. The anterior surface forms the superior part of the trochlear notch. The olecranon provides insertion for the triceps brachii and anconeus muscles.
clinical_significance: **Olecranon fractures** commonly result from direct falls on elbow. **Olecranon bursitis** (student's elbow) causes posterior swelling. **Tension band wiring** is used to repair transverse fractures. **Stress fractures** occur in throwing athletes. The olecranon is a key landmark for **elbow aspiration** and **nerve blocks**. **Heterotopic ossification** can occur post-trauma.
blood_supply: Superior and inferior ulnar collateral arteries, posterior ulnar recurrent artery

definition_brief: Triangular anterior projection of proximal ulna forming inferior boundary of trochlear notch
description_full: The coronoid process is a triangular projection that extends anteriorly from the proximal ulna, forming the inferior boundary of the trochlear notch. It has a superior articular surface that articulates with the trochlea, a medial surface, and a lateral surface bearing the radial notch. The tip and inferior surface provide attachment for brachialis and the anterior bundle of the ulnar collateral ligament.
clinical_significance: **Coronoid fractures** are classified by Regan-Morrey and O'Driscoll systems and critically affect **elbow stability**. **Terrible triad** injury involves coronoid fracture, radial head fracture, and elbow dislocation. **Coronoid impingement** can limit flexion. Fractures involving >50% of coronoid height cause **posterior instability**. Surgical fixation may require **open reduction**.
blood_supply: Anterior ulnar recurrent artery, ulnar artery

definition_brief: Large C-shaped articular surface on proximal ulna articulating with humeral trochlea
description_full: The trochlear notch is a large, C-shaped articular surface on the anterior aspect of the proximal ulna. It is formed by the olecranon superiorly and the coronoid process inferiorly. The notch articulates with the trochlea of the humerus in a hinge-like manner, allowing flexion and extension. A vertical ridge divides the notch into medial and lateral parts, corresponding to the grooved trochlea.
clinical_significance: The trochlear notch provides primary **bony stability** to the elbow joint. **Elbow dislocations** typically involve posterior displacement from this articulation. **Osteoarthritis** causes joint space narrowing and osteophyte formation. **Loose bodies** can cause mechanical locking. The notch anatomy determines **arc of motion** and is critical in **total elbow arthroplasty** design.
blood_supply: Superior and inferior ulnar collateral arteries, anterior and posterior ulnar recurrent arteries

definition_brief: Small conical projection on posteromedial aspect of distal ulna
description_full: The ulnar styloid process is a short, conical projection from the posteromedial aspect of the distal ulna. It provides attachment for the ulnar collateral ligament of the wrist and the triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC). The styloid lies approximately 1 cm proximal to the radial styloid in neutral position.
clinical_significance: **Ulnar styloid fractures** commonly accompany distal radius fractures. **TFCC tears** can occur with styloid fractures. **Ulnar impaction syndrome** involves abnormal loading between ulna and carpus. **Non-union** of styloid fractures may cause ulnar-sided wrist pain. The styloid is a key landmark for assessing **ulnar variance** on radiographs.
blood_supply: Ulnar artery, anterior and posterior interosseous arteries
